response:
The chat between Rahil and Faraz is about Rahil's difficulty in connecting to GitHub remote. Rahil says that he has spent more time trying to connect to GitHub remote than he has spent on coding or searching. He also says that this is a common pattern he has seen, where 20% of his time is spent on coding or searching and 80% of his time is spent on connecting to GitHub remote.

Faraz asks Rahil what he means by "connecting to GitHub remote." Rahil explains that he is trying to push code to GitHub.com. Faraz suggests that Rahil use SSH to connect to GitHub.com. Rahil agrees and says that he will set up SSH.

Later, Rahil tells Faraz that setting up SSH did the trick. He is now able to connect to GitHub remote and push code to GitHub.com.

My opinion is that Rahil's experience is a common one. Many developers struggle with connecting to GitHub remote. There are a number of reasons for this, including:

* GitHub remote can be difficult to configure.
* GitHub remote can be slow.
* GitHub remote can be unreliable.

If you are having trouble connecting to GitHub remote, I recommend that you try the following:

* Make sure that you have the correct credentials.
* Check your network connection.
* Try using a different method of connecting to GitHub, such as SSH or HTTPS.
* If you are still having trouble, contact GitHub support.

I hope this helps!
